docs.lead_paragraph: For anyone who spent months watching the Democrats' family feud over a proposed government-run health insurance plan, or the more recent intraparty battle between House and Senate Democrats over a proposed tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance policies, it might have seemed as if Republicans were much more unified on the issue of health care.
docs.abstract: Republicans have their differences, too. There is no agreement, for instance, on how to step back from an employee tax break that most experts agree is unfair.
docs.snippet: Republicans have their differences, too. There is no agreement, for instance, on how to step back from an employee tax break that most experts agree is unfair.

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Pear and David M. Herszenhorn summarize Republican positions on pending health care legislation, while Reed Abelson reports that without significant changes to the system, smaller hospitals are likely to see their finances deteriorate as they are forced to treat more patients without insurance. Please share your thoughts in the comments section.
docs.abstract: The Times takes a look at Republican ideas and the poor prognosis for smaller hospitals.
docs.snippet: The Times takes a look at Republican ideas and the poor prognosis for smaller hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Washington area now expects more snow later today and on Wednesday, complicating votes on Capitol Hill and canceling work for thousands of federal employees.
docs.abstract: The weather continues to wreak a little havoc in Washington.
docs.snippet: The weather continues to wreak a little havoc in Washington.

headline.main: How to Reduce the Federal Deficit
headline.print_headline: How to Reduce the Federal Deficit

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans this month will bring President Obama a set of ideas and a more modest health care plan.

headline.main: On Health Bill, G.O.P.’s Road Is a New Map
headline.print_headline: On Health Bill, G.O.P.’s Road Is a New Map

docs.snippet: Republicans this month will bring President Obama a set of ideas and a more modest health care plan.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: While the debate continues in Washington, health care systems nationwide struggle to offset money spent to treat patients who cannot afford to pay their bills.

headline.seo: Hospitals Suffer as Health Care Legislation Stalls
headline.main: Bills Stalled, Hospitals Fear Rising Unpaid Care
headline.print_headline: Bills Stalled, Hospitals Fear Rising Unpaid Care

docs.snippet: While the debate continues in Washington, health care systems nationwide struggle to offset money spent to treat patients who cannot afford to pay their bills.

keywords.value: North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Throughout the health care debate over the last year, Representative Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York, needled President Obama and Democratic leaders in Congress for not sticking to their liberal ideals and being too willing to compromise on the idea of a government-run health insurance plan, or public option.

headline.main: Weiner on Bipartisanship: 'Good Luck With That'

docs.abstract: A leading liberal remains skeptical of Republican cooperation.
docs.snippet: A leading liberal remains skeptical of Republican cooperation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, praised President Obama's call for a bipartisan summit meeting on health care legislation and suggested that there are two plans that could serve as a basis for compromise: a proposal that he developed called "Coverage, Prevention, Reform" - C.P.R., for short - and a bill put forward by Senators Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Bob Bennett, Republican of Utah.

headline.main: Gregg Proposes Starting Points for Bipartisan Talks

docs.abstract: The senior Republican on the Senate budget committee warns against using talks as an "arena for public theater."
docs.snippet: The senior Republican on the Senate budget committee warns against using talks as an "arena for public theater."

docs.lead_paragraph: The top two House Republicans, Representatives John A. Boehner of Ohio and Eric Cantor of Virginia, sent a letter to the White House on Monday urging Democrats to scrap their existing health care legislation ahead of President Obama's bipartisan summit meeting.

headline.main: House Republicans Urge Democrats to 'Scrap' Health Bills

docs.abstract: In a letter sent to the White House on Monday, Republican House leaders, ""If the starting point for this meeting is the job-killing bills the American people have already soundly rejected, Republicans would rightly be reluctant to participate."
docs.snippet: In a letter sent to the White House on Monday, Republican House leaders, ""If the starting point for this meeting is the job-killing bills the American people have already soundly rejected, Republicans would rightly be reluctant to participate."

headline.main: Updated: Sebelius Asks California Insurer to Explain Rate Increase

docs.abstract: The Secretary of Health and Human Services wants to know why Anthem Blue Cross is raising premiums by as much as 39 percent.
docs.snippet: The Secretary of Health and Human Services wants to know why Anthem Blue Cross is raising premiums by as much as 39 percent.
